block.p: Hyperion announced yesterday that it would publish a manuscript presented as the diary of Jack the Ripper, even though another publisher, Warner Books, asserted last week that the diary was fake and canceled its own publication plans.

"This is a fascinating document, and the questions it raises are equally absorbing," Robert Miller, the vice president and publisher of Hyperion, said in a statement. Referring to an independent analysis saying that the diaries had been written between 1909 and 1933 -- not in the 1880's, when Jack the Ripper was terrorizing London -- Mr. Miller said: "Certainly, if it is a hoax, it is a very old and elaborate one -- who did write this -- and why?"

Hyperion announced yesterday that it would publish a manuscript presented as the diary of Jack the Ripper, even though another publisher, Warner Books, asserted last week that the diary was fake and canceled its own publication plans.

"This is a fascinating document, and the questions it raises are equally absorbing," Robert Miller, the vice president and publisher of Hyperion, said in a statement. Referring to an independent analysis saying that the diaries had been written between 1909 and 1933 -- not in the 1880's, when Jack the Ripper was terrorizing London -- Mr. Miller said: "Certainly, if it is a hoax, it is a very old and elaborate one -- who did write this -- and why?"

The book, which is to include the text of the diary and a discussion of whether it is authentic, is to be published in October. In addition, Smith Gryphon, a British publisher, said it would go ahead with its own plans to publish the book.
